comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: "... was erected in 1879 to mark the centenary of his death. It stands near the corner of Park and College streets, the highest point in the park. Its sculptor was Thomas Woolmer [sic] who was prominent in the English Pre-Raphaelite movement and spent several years in Australia." - from Dictionary of Sydney: Hyde Park by Anne-Maree Whitaker, 2008

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Wonderfully irreverent and tongue-in-cheek description of this statue and the marble column here - www.publicartaroundtheworld.com/Captain_Cook_Statue_Sydne...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: This is intriguing. There was an earlier statue of Captain Cook in Hyde Park, before the one that was unveiled in 1879 (which was commissioned in 1874). "CAPTAIN COOK'S STATUE Sir, - While crossing Hyde Park yesterday I stopped to read the inscription, or intended inscription. On coming to the place where he was killed, I thought it would be a pity to let this pass unnoticed, as it is not properly spelled, or the place known, perhaps, but by a few. It reads thus:- "Killed at Owhyhee in 1779." Now, how many persons know anything of this island by the above inscription? I venture to say very few indeed. I beg to suggest to those who have the management of the inscription the following:- "Killed at Kealakeakua, Island of Hawaii, Sandwich Islands, 1779." This would be proper, as it is the present style of spelling the name of that island, and the place at which he was killed. I most respectfully offer this suggestion before the inscription is cut, which is at present only painted. Yours, &c., An Observer. August 18" - SMH Friday 19/8/1870 p.5 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13213887 I wonder if we can find any photographs of it?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] I love a mystery and treasure Trove hunt. Alas, I think what the 'Observer' saw was an "intended inscription" for the statue we now see, which took yonks to organize and erect. The foundation stone was laid by Prince Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh in March 1869, see full description in SMH 29/3/1869 p.5 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13179028 . It then took ten years to complete. Committee Quotes !

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: There is a great newspaper article about the unveiling on Trove. "... in the presence of between 30,000 and 40,000 persons. There was a procession two miles in length, composed of marines, naval and all other fire and military brigades, every associated body, and 13 bands....Three hundred girls between the ages of 10 and 14, dressed in while and blue and sailors' hats, sang "Rule Britannia" and "God Save the Queen." 'The statue, which had been enshrouded in a Union Jack, was unveiled by six sailors, who ascended amid deafening enthusiasm. This is acknowledged to have been the most patriotic ceremony which has ever taken place in New South Wales...." I have added the date "after 25 Feb 1879" above. AB

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] I want it to the nearest hour! I spent a while on a Trove Picture search of captain cooks statue (earliest first) - there are 155 photos in roughly chronological order; most irrelevant. It is possible to see the statue from just a pedestal, to the unveiling, plantings around, etc. I think it is the vegetation size which will help date this photo to c.1885. Not just the relatively new garden around the statue, but the Bunyah Pines in the background. They are still there from Google Street View - and last about 500 years!
